newsitem.title: USA: USDA lifts restrictions on Spanish pork.
newsitem.headline: USDA lifts restrictions on Spanish pork.

text.p: The U.S. Department of Agriculture said Thursday it was lifting certain restrictions on the importation of pork products from Spain by declaring that nation free of African swine fever (ASF).
The order, contained in the Federal Register, becomes effective September 6 and follows a proposal in late May to declare Spain ASF free.

Although increased imports into the United States from Spain of dry-cured ham and sausages were anticipated, the USDA estimated the maximum amount of cured pork that Spain could expect to export to the United States "will likely not exceed 500 metric tons annually..."

It added that this ceiling was unlikely to be reached for a period of about five years because the imports from Spain would still be required to meet Food Safety and Inspection Service standards before entering the country.
